text: this rising chain looks like a great
magic trick but it's more unusual than
that it's a brand new problem in the
physics of everyday things and it was
discovered by a TV personality
Steve mole who studied physics at Oxford
stumbled on the chain fountain while he
was looking for a way to demonstrate
something else entirely his online video
of the phenomenon went viral and it
caught the attention of two physicists
at Cambridge John bagans and Mark Warner
they thought great this would be a
perfect problem for high school physics
students to work then they realized they
didn't understand what was actually
going on they tried a lot of different
kinds of chains including even linked
noodles it was clear enough that the
chain was flowing down pulled by gravity
the way water gasoline flows when it's
siphoned out of the tank but what caused
the fountain the rising curve with its
twists and turns mathematically all
chains act like connected rods push one
end up and the other end goes down but
as the moving chain pulls one end of a
link up and the other end tries to go
down it runs into the pile of chain
beneath
the kickback pushes that link up
creating the fountain
problem solved and the best part is it
is all Newtonian physics so it's a great
problem for high school students
